title: What are some tips for writing dialogue in a novel? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m more a playwright than I am a writer of prose fiction. But then your average play is more dialogue-based than just about anything you’re likely to read. Here are a few things I’ve learned. Real people don’t always say the right thing. Ironically, one sign of poor dialogue (if you’re trying to be realistic, at least) is a certain excess of cleverness. Even the most charismatic speakers are imperfect if you listen critically. The most confident people get tongue-tied. The most talkative people can be stunned into silence. Implausibly witty banter is a symptom of implausibly perfect characters. It’s not that your characters can’t be smart or articulate. But they should sound human. Real people don’t always say what they mean. Another sign of poor dialogue is the absence of subtext — characters who only seem to speak to tell us what they’re thinking and feeling. It’s not that every line needs to drip with subtext, but think about it: how often do people tell you what’s really going on in their heads? What they really want? Your co-worker might desperately confess his love for you in a fit of pique, but if he’s sane he already tried telling you a hundred different ways before actually telling you. Real people only speak when they want something. Even if they just want to hear the sound of their own voice. If you know what your character wants, you’ll know what she needs to say — or not say — to get it. If your character is talking but she doesn’t seem to want anything then why the fuck is she talking? Real people play many roles. Do you speak to your uncle the same way you speak to your lover? Unless you’re fucking your uncle, probably not. We all play many roles as we navigate the world, and we all try to adapt ourselves to thrive in those roles. A generally nasty, arrogant person may suddenly become a saint when her grandmother shows up. Remember: your character is also an actor. Don’t be too real. Human speech is a lot less fluent and coherent than we like to imagine. We make little detours, we trail off, we cough, we mumble, we stumble, we misuse words, we repeat ourselves. We’re a mess. But writing dialogue is an art: it entails creating a stylized version of the truth. So go easy on um and er and ... There’s a fine line between realism and real life.

I see a lot of ‘said is dead’ discourse going on in the answers. ‘Stop using said’ is one of the first things English teachers try to enforce in order to inspire better dialogue. Unfortunately, it’s also completely misguided. Let me give you an example. “Hello,” I said. “Hi,” she said. “Great weather today,” I said. “I prefer rain,” she said. Very flat, boring dialogue. Let’s try the said is dead method. “Hello,” I muttered. “Hi,” she whispered. “Great weather today,” I declared. “I prefer rain,” she groaned. Still flat and boring, with an extra dose of awkward. Now let’s try something different. “Hello,” I said, sidling up to the girl at the bus stop, my hands in my pockets. I cleared my throat, trying to steady my nerves. “Hi,” she replied, not looking at me, but staring down at her phone. As I moved closer, she took a step away. “Great weather today,” I said, my voice breaking. I cleared my throat again, feeling the heat of embarrassment creep up the back of my neck. “There’s lots of, uh, clouds?” She looked up at me briefly, her stare flat and unimpressed, the slightest curl of disdain in her lip. Without breaking eye contact, she turned off her phone and shoved it into her pocket. “I prefer rain.” She turned her back on me and hurried away down the street, in the direction of the next nearest bus stop, nearly a block away. The problem which ‘said is dead’ tries and fails to address is the problem of flat, repetitive dialogue that doesn't convey anything except a script of what’s being said. A much more effective way to fix boring dialogue is to break it up with description that enhances your story, makes it easier for your readers to visualize what’s happening, and communicates something about the characters and setting. Describe how they say what they’re saying, what they’re doing when they say it, and try to communicate how they feel about what they’re saying. Here’s an example with three people saying the same line in a different way. “I hate Mondays,” he said, hunching his shoulders and kicking at the gravel like a petulant teenager. “I hate Mondays,” she said with a grin and a wink, and reached for another slice of lasagna. “I hate Mondays,” he said, voice distant, his attention focused on the paperwork he was shuffling through. If the line was just “I hate Mondays” he said, it communicates much less. By elaborating on their actions as they speak, you get vital context on how they actually feel about it. Varying your sentence structure is another way to improve flow. See how in the bus stop example it isn’t just ‘“words” he said.’ But also ‘“words,” he said, “and more words”’ and also occasionally omitting the dialogue tag entirely when it’s obvious who’s speaking. Mixing it up like this keeps your dialogue more dynamic and interesting to read. A few other dialogue tips- Finding your character’s voices is important to making sure they don’t all sound like the same person. Try to have an idea of each character’s unique personality, and a general idea of their likes, dislikes, and experiences. Making a small list or breakdown of these traits can help you keep track of them. Are they generally cheerful or stoic? Do they enjoy science fiction, hate big crowds? Did they grow up in the city or out in the country? All of these things color how they view the world and how they interact with other characters. A cheerful sci fi lover might crack pop culture jokes with his friends. A stoic cowboy might use his words sparingly. If the character is from the country, they might have a different idea of what’s polite than a character from the city. Avoid writing accents, stutters or inflections. You can imply an accent or stutter with word choice and other character building details. But actually writing out the accent (dropping letters and spelling words phonetically) tends to come across as a bad stereotype, and frequently kills the mood of whatever scene it happens in. Always be reading. The single best thing you can do for your writing skills, dialogue included, is to keep reading! Try the old classics, try new experimental stuff too. Push yourself to try books that might be out of your skill range or usual wheelhouse. Experiment in other genres. Indulge heavily in your favorites, because that’s where you’ll find the techniques that will help you most, but never be afraid to branch out. I always recommend China Mieville because he’s a master of using language in new and interesting ways. I try to read a chapter every night, and often end up spending my whole day off engrossed in a book. It’s the best thing you can do for yourself as a writer.
